Though the expression ‘aperto iure’ in the text above might seem to imply that the counter claim must have been proved and established in an independent action, it seems better to understand this passage to mean that the proof and aestimatio of the counter claim must not be so intricate as to practically reverse the respective rdles of the parties, and as it were to turn the defendant into a plaintifi'.

Great difficulty is occasioned by the expression ‘actiones ipso iure minuant' in the text, and by the attribution even in juristic writings (eg. Dig. 16. 2. 4; ib. ro. pr.; ib. 21) to compensatio of an operation ‘ipso iure' The standing opposition, in modes by which obligations were in· validated, between invalidation ipso iure and invalidation ope exceptionis (p. 448 supr.) has led some commentatore to interpret these passages by representing set-off as by it'self (or ‘sine facto hominis’) absolutely extinguishing the plaintifi's claim, so far as it goes ; but if this were so, such a tacit or automatic reduction of that claim would take place in all cases where the defendant had a set-off, whether the latter wished it or not; a hypothesis which is sufficiently disproved by Dig. 27. 4. r. 4 ‘praeterea si tutelae iudicio quis convenietur, reputare potest id, quod in rem pupilli impendit, sic erit arbitrii eius, utrum compensare, an petere velit sumtus,' and Dig. 16. a. 7. r ‘si rationem compensationis iudex non habuerit, salva manet petitio) 'ibe real meaning of the expression seems to be that, though the defendant, if he wishes to set-off against the plaintiff, must plead his claim, yet, immediately he has pleaded and proved it, its operation relates baclr to the moment at which the two claims first coexisted: ‘si constat, pecuniam invicem deberi, ipso iure pro soluto compensationem haberi oportet ex eo tempore, ex quo ab utraque debetur, utique quoad concurrentes quantitates, eiusque solius, quod amplius apud alterum est, usurae debentur, si modo earum petitio subsistit’ Cod. 4. 3¹· 43 hom that moment no interest can be claimed, except on the balance, Cod. ib., Dig. 16. 2. rr ; and if the defendant for· gets to set-off, he can recover what he has pald in excess by condictio indebiti, Dig. ib. ro. r ; 12. 6. 30.
